questions.question_text: Which of the following are replication methods available in Vault Enterprise? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Screenshot is choices from the Enable a Secrets Engine section of the UI.

Selected Answer: D
This statement is partially correct. The command is indeed using the AppRole authentication method to log in with a specified role ID and secret ID. However, it’s not configuring the AppRole auth method; it’s using it to authenticate and obtain a token. Configuration of AppRole involves setting up roles and associated policies, which is not what this command is doing.

So, based on the information provided, the accurate description of the command and its output is not fully captured by any of the listed statements. The closest accurate statement is D, but it should be noted that the command is for authentication, not configuration.

Selected Answer: A
A is more correct

auth/my-path/login API endpoint is used for authentication, but not configuring custom/static role_id/secret_id, so the right answer here should be A, since default policy is missing from the output.
Answer A

Selected Answer: D
Correct statement as per https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/auth/approle#authentication and https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/auth/approle#credentials-constraints

choices.C: Generated token is an orphan token which can be renewed indefinitely
choices.D: Configures the AppRole auth method with user specified role ID and secret ID

questions.question_text: You have a 2GB Base64 binary large object (blob) that needs to be encrypted. Which of the following best describes the transit secrets engine?

choices.B: To process such a large blob. Vault will temporarily store it in the storage backend.
choices.A: A data key encrypts the blob locally, and the same key decrypts the blob locally.
choices.C: Vault will store the blob permanently. Be sure to run Vault on a compute optimized machine.
choices.D: The transit engine is not a good solution for binaries of this size.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
The KV Put and KV Get operations require the read, create, and update capabilities granted in the first part of the policy so A & B are correct.
Metadata is not one of the listed capabilities in the first section of the policy so C is wrong.
The deny in the second part of the policy prevents D & E.
